Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 09:11PM darah58 wrote: Hello to you all, I have one more rad treatment to go.  I have been doing very well, so I thought I would send my best advice to you who are yet to begin.  Skin:  I used calendula cream (marigold-extract cream from Whole Foods) three times daily.  My radiation oncologist recommended this and, after five weeks, my skin is still supple and I only now have some redness under my arm.  Fatigue:  If you already have an exercise program, stick with it.  I have been doing pilates for six years -- continued during radiation 4x weekly -- and it has been so, so good for me.  I had lumpectomy for DCIS -- no mastectomy or chemo -- but stretch as much as you can comfortably do it.  Some of us have underarm stiffness, so work on keeping your muscles flexible.  Rest when you can, and don't try to be too brave.  Deodorant:  I have been using Tom's of Maine Calendula deodorant.  It's been working well, and I have also been using cornstarch powder for my underarm and under-breast area.  Shaving:  I bought a battery-operated razor at CVS, and I use it every Sunday.  I hadn't used an "electric" razor since I was 14, but this has worked well, and it has not exacerbated underarm irritation. Bra:  Many people on this site have recommended good bras.  I've been using a Title Nine sports bra, but I only wear it for exercise.  If you can possibly do without it, do not wear a bra. Hope this is helpful.  I'll post again if I remember anything more. Darah

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 11:42PM darah58 wrote: Dragonfly, I did not have chemo, but I did find rads quite terrifying initially.  (Did rads from 21 January to 3 March 2008) All I could think of was Chernobyl.  I agree with Shirlann -- I took .5 mg of ativan before most sessions and it helped a lot.  I also went to a cognitive therapist --paid for by the hospital -- and that helped too.  My treatments were always at 12:15, so I always went out to lunch afterwards.  Sometimes with friends or my husband, sometimes just with a good book.  Mostly, though, I just got used to it over time.  Somewhere during the third week I found I could relax just a bit more than previously. I am glad to have done it, following two excisions for DCIS.  You should definitely ask your rad onc any questions you may have.  Good luck to you, and please let us know how things go with you. Darah

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2008 08:20PM darah58 wrote: Clueless, I wanted to let you know that when I said two days ago that I was pleased with the way my breasts looked, it was two-months post-rads, not two months after excision.  I had a needle-biopsy in mid-August, several MRI-guided biopsies shortly afterwards, a left breast excision (DCIS) at the end of August, and a re-excision in November.  I went through rads from late January to early March.  Both breasts were terribly bruised after all of the biopsies/excisions.  I tolerated rads very well.  I've been happy with my healing -- I barely notice a difference now -- though I don't really think that it's anything I did.  I had a good surgeon, I took care of myself, and I let time take its course.  When I went through rads, I used calendula cream 3x/daily.  Please do not worry too much about scars, etc.  Time takes care of it, and the scars from lumpectomy are less scary than you imagine, Wishing you the Best, Darah
